visit.description: Met with President Truman after receiving medical treatment in Baltimore (Maryland). In U.S. January 7–February 6.
At invitation of the President. Also visited New York City, Philadelphia (Pennsylvania), Tennessee, Texas, and New Orleans (Louisiana). Departed U.S. May 3.
Official visit. Afterwards visited New York City, Chicago, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Houston, New Orleans (Louisiana), Schenectady (New York), and Boston (Massachusetts). Departed U.S. May 30.
Met with President Truman en route to London.
Discussed the military situation in Korea and developments in the Far East and Europe with President Truman.
At the invitation of the President. Discussed collective security in the Far East and Europe with President Truman.
Met with President Truman February 8 while returning from a Commonwealth conference in London.
Addressed U.S. Congress April 2. Afterwards visited New York City. Departed U.S. April 4.
Met with President Truman April 9 during a private visit. Arrived in U.S. March 31; visited New York City.
Unofficial visit. Had come to Baltimore (Maryland) in February for medical treatment at Johns Hopkins Hospital.

Goodwill visit and promotion of Israel Bonds. Also visited Knoxville (Tennessee), New York City, West Point (New York), Philadelphia (Pennsylvania), Princeton (New Jersey), Baltimore (Maryland), Boston (Massachusetts), Pittsburgh (Pennsylvania), Chicago, Detroit (Michigan), Cleveland (Ohio), Los Angeles. Departed U.S. May 31.
In the U.S. May 15–29, visiting New York City and ethnic communities in the Midwest and Far West.
Guest of U.S. Government. Addressed U.S. Congress June 21. Afterwards visited New York City and San Francisco. Departed U.S. June 29.
Signed a security treaty.
Attended the Japanese Peace Conference in San Francisco.
Attended the Japanese Peace Conference in San Francisco.
At invitation of the U.S. Government. Met with President Truman after a NATO meeting in Ottawa, Canada. Addressed U.S. Congress September 24.
Discussed the Anglo-Iranian oil dispute after appearing at the UN Arrived in U.S. October 8.
Revisited Washington January 16–19. Addressed U.S. Congress January 17.
Informal visit. In U.S. January 12–24, visiting New York City, Bridgeport (Connecticut) and Pittsburgh (Pennsylvania).

Addressed U.S. Congress April 3. Afterwards visited Philadelphia (Pennsylvania), New York City, Knoxville (Tennessee), Detroit, Grand Rapids, Holland, and Ann Arbor, (Michigan), San Francisco, and Los Angeles. Departed U.S. April 22.
Unofficial visit. In U.S. April 3–17. Also visited New York City, Rockford (Illinois), Chicago, Minneapolis (Minnesota), and Detroit (Michigan).
Unofficial visit to Washington. Afterwards visited Boston (Massachusetts) and New York City. Departed U.S. July 5.
At the invitation of the U.S. Government. In U.S. May 11–27. Visited New York City, Williamsburg (Virginia), Buffalo (New York), Detroit (Michigan), Chicago, and Madison (Wisconsin).
Informal discussions en route to London.

Informal, unofficial visit. In U.S. August 12–September 17. Visited New York City ,Detroit (Michigan), Chicago, Denver (Colorado), San Francisco, Las Vegas (Nevada), Phoenix (Arizona), Muscle Shoals (Tennessee), and Fort Knox (Kentucky).
In U.S. September 10–30. Also visited New York City, Detroit (Michigan), Duluth and Minneapolis (Minnesota), Chicago, and Madison (Wisconsin).
Met with President-elect Eisenhower in New York City.
Unofficial visit.
Official visit. Discussed security measures in the Far East and Europe.
Guest of the President. In U.S. April 6–18. Visited San Francisco, Carmel (California), Chicago, New York City, and Boston (Massachusetts).
En route from Europe to Cambodia; visited New York City and San Francisco. Departed U.S. April 21.
Guest of the President. Discussed bilateral relations.
Met with President Eisenhower en route to London for the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II.
Discussed terms of the Korean truce agreement with President Eisenhower and senior officials.
Private visit to Washington, D.C. after medical treatment in Baltimore (Maryland). In U.S. July 1–August 24.
Afterwards made an unofficial visit to New York City. Departed U.S. October 7.
Met with President Eisenhower in Texas for dedication of Falcon Dam.

At the invitation of the President. Afterwards visited Philadelphia (Pennsylvania), New York City, Boston (Massachusetts), Toledo (Ohio), Detroit (Michigan), Chicago, San Francisco, Los Angeles, the Grand Canyon (Arizona), Houston (Texas), New Orleans (Louisiana), and Williamsburg (Virginia). Private visit to New York City from November 24. Departed U.S. December 3.
Met with President Eisenhower after obtaining medical treatment in Boston (Massachusetts).

At the invitation of the President. Addressed U.S. Congress January 29. Afterwards visited Princeton (New Jersey), New York City, Cleveland and Toledo (Ohio), Chicago, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Las Vegas (Nevada), Dallas (Texas), and Raleigh (North Carolina). Private visit to New York City February 20. Departed U.S. February 27.
Addressed U.S. Congress May 4.

At the invitation of the President. Addressed U.S. Congress May 4. Afterwards visited Princeton (New Jersey), New York City, Boston (Massachusetts), Ann Arbor and Lansing (Michigan), Chicago, St. Paul (Minnesota), Spokane and Seattle (Washington), San Francisco, Los Angeles, New Orleans (Louisiana), Stillwater (Oklahoma), and Fort Benning (Georgia). Also traveled to Canada (June 3–7) and Mexico (June 19–24). Left U.S. July 12.
Official visit. Discussed economic and financial matters.
Informal visit to Washington.
Unofficial visit. Discussed U.S. military base rights and economic assistance.
State visit. Afterwards visited New York City, Philadelphia (Pennsylvania), Chicago, Kansas City (Missouri), Los Angeles, and San Francisco. Departed U.S. August 8.
Official guest.
State visit. In U.S. October 16–November 12, visiting Akron, Chicago, Springfield (Ill.), Detroit, Cleveland, New York City, Tuskegee (Ala.), and Atlanta.
Signed Treaty of Friendship, Commerce and Navigation. Afterwards visited New York City. Departed U.S. November 1.
In U.S. November 2–14, while returning from Europe, visiting New York City, San Francisco and Honolulu (Hawaii).
Discussed European and Far Eastern affairs, visited New York City, and addressed UN General Assembly. Departed U.S. November 23.
Official visit. Afterwards visited Miami, New Orleans, St. Louis, and New York City. Departed U.S. December 5. Stopped in New York City December 9 after visiting Canada.
Arrived in U.S. November 16, aboard inaugural trans-Arctic flight to Los Angeles by Scandinavian Airlines. Met with President Eisenhower November 24.
Arrived in U.S. November 16, aboard inaugural trans-Arctic flight to Los Angeles by Scandinavian Airlines. Met with President Eisenhower November 24.
Arrived in U.S. November 16, aboard inaugural trans-Arctic flight to Los Angeles by Scandinavian Airlines. Met with President Eisenhower November 24.
Official visit. Afterwards visited Akron (Ohio), Los Angeles, San Francisco, and Honolulu (Hawaii).
Unofficial visit. Afterwards visited San Francisco, Sun Valley (Idaho), and New York City. Departed U.S. February 11, 1955.
Unofficial visit. Left New York City January 27.

Official visit. Addressed U.S. Congress January 27. Afterwards visited West Point (New York) and New York City. After February 3 unofficially visited Nashville (Tennessee), Chicago and Boston (Massachusetts). Departed U.S. February 9.
Official visit. In New York City March 5–9; visited Canada March 9–13. Addressed U.S. Congress March 16. Private visit after March 17.
Official visit. Also visited New York City. Unofficial visits to Philadelphia, Chicago, and Detroit. Departed U.S. April 7.
Official visit. In U.S. April 23–May 1, visiting San Francisco, Detroit, Albany, New York City, West Point and Hyde Park (New York), and Morrisville (Pennsylvania).
Unofficial visit. Also visited Boston (Massachusetts) and New York City. Departed the U.S. June 18.
Official visit. In U.S. June 24–July 16. Visited New York City, Detroit (Michigan), Knoxville (Tennessee), the Grand Canyon (Arizona), Los Angeles, and San Francisco.
Official visit. Afterwards visited New York City, St. Louis (Missouri), Houston (Texas), and New Orleans (Louisiana). Departed U.S. November 13.
Official visit. Afterwards visited New York City, Boston (Massachusetts), Chicago, and Miami. Departed U.S. December 17.
Met with President Eisenhower at Key West (Florida) and with other officials in Washington. Afterwards visited New York City. Departed U.S. January 9.
Met with President Eisenhower, addressed U.S. Congress, and issued Joint Declaration on common principles.
State visit. Addressed U.S. Congress February 29. Afterwards visited Norfolk (Virginia), Detroit (Michigan), San Francisco, and New York City. Visited Canada March 3–5. Departed U.S. March 14.
Afterwards visited New York City, Philadelphia (Pennsylvania), and New Haven (Connecticut). Departed U.S. March 29.
Attended a Heads of Government meeting in White Sulphur Springs (West Virginia).
Attended a Heads of Government meeting in White Sulphur Springs (West Virginia).

State visit. Addressed U.S. Congress May 17. Afterwards visited Charlottesville (Virginia), Annapolis (Maryland), New York City, Philadelphia (Pennsylvania), Springfield (Illinois), Detroit (Michigan), the Grand Canyon (Arizona), Los Angeles, Salt Lake City (Utah), and Niagara Falls (New York). Departed U.S. June 3.
In U.S. June 9–15, visiting New York City, New Haven (Connecticut), Chicago and Milwaukee (Wisconsin). Departed U.S. June 15.
Unofficial visit following Commonwealth Prime Ministers’ Conference in London. In New York City July 21–26.
Discussed the Suez Crisis with President Eisenhower and senior U.S. officials.
Unofficial courtesy call. In U.S. September 13–November 7, visiting New York City, Philadelphia (Pennsylvania), and Atlantic City (New Jersey).
Met with U.S. officials while attending a UN General Assembly session.
Official visit at Washington and Gettysburg (Pennsylvania).
State visit to Washington.
Official visit. Afterwards visited New York City. Departed U.S. March 2.

State visit. In the U.S. May 5–May 21. Also visited Honolulu (Hawaii), San Francisco, New York City, Detroit and Lansing (Michigan), Knoxville (Tennessee), and Los Angeles. Addressed U.S. Congress May 9.
Official visit. Private visit to New York City and Greenwich (Connecticut) May 24–25.
Official visit. In U.S. June 16–29. Also visited Honolulu (Hawaii), San Francisco, New York City and Los Angeles.

Official visit. Afterwards visited Colorado Springs (Colorado), the Grand Canyon (Arizona), Los Angeles, San Francisco, Salt Lake City (Utah), Omaha (Nebraska), Detroit (Michigan), and New York City. Departed U.S. July 27.
Accompanied Queen Elizabeth II.
Attended ceremonies for the350th anniversary of the first permanent English settlement in America. In U.S. June 16–21, visited Jamestown and Williamsburg (Virginia), Washington, and New York City.
Informal meeting with President Eisenhower.
State visit. Afterwards visited Williamsburg (Virginia), Dallas (Texas), Los Angeles, San Francisco, Omaha (Nebraska), Niagara Falls (ew York), and New York City. Departed U.S. December 13.
Private visit to obtain medical treatment. Met with President Eisenhower December 23.
Informal meetings with President Eisenhower and senior U.S. officials.
Also visited Houston (Texas). Departed U.S. February 26.
At the invitation of the President. In U.S. March 25–31. Also visited New Orleans (Louisiana) and New York City.
Unofficial visit; attended Minnesota Statehood Centennial in Minneapolis and St. Paul.
Unofficial visit; attended Minnesota Statehood Centennial in Minneapolis and St. Paul.
Unofficial visit; attended Minnesota Statehood Centennial in Minneapolis and St. Paul.
Unofficial visit. In U.S. May 17–28; visited New York City, Chicago, and San Francisco.

State visit. Addressed U.S. Congress June 5. Afterwards visited Philadelphia, Hanover (New Hampshire), Detroit (Michigan), Chicago, San Francisco, the Grand Canyon (Arizona), Williamsburg and Charlottesville (Virginia), and New York City. Departed U.S. June 23.
Unofficial visit. Met informally with the President, also visited Greencastle (Indiana), and Baltimore (Maryland).
State visit. In U.S. June 15–July 1. Addressed U.S. Congress June 18. Also visited Chicago, New York City, Phoenix (Arizona), Los Angeles and San Francisco.

Official visit; signed a cultural agreement. Visited Detroit (Michigan), Niagara Falls (New York), Fort Bragg (North Carolina), Knoxville and Oak Ridge (Tennessee), Los Angeles, San Francisco, Laramie and Yellowstone Park (Wyoming), and New York City. Left U.S. July 13.
Informal visit. In U.S. June 1–July 3. Also visited Hawaii, San Francisco, Minneapolis (Minnesota), Springfield (Massachusetts), and New York City.
Official visit. Afterwards visited Hershey, Harrisburg and Philadelphia (Pennyslvania), New York City, and Chicago. Departed U.S. August 2.
Informal visit to Washington.
Unofficial visit to Washington while attending UN General Assembly. Arrived in U.S. September 12.
State visit. In U.S. January 19–February 1, visited Miami (Florida), Houston (Texas), Chicago, Detroit (Michigan), and New York City. Addressed U.S. Congress January 21.
State visit. In U.S. March 9–21; visited Charlottesville (Virginia), New York City, Springfield (Illinois), Houston (Texas), and New Orleans (Louisiana). Addressed U.S. Congress March 11.

At the invitation of the President. In the U.S. March 16–31. Also visited New York City, Providence (Rhode Island), Boston, Chicago, Springfield and Peoria (Illinois), St. Paul (Minnesota), and Philadelphia (Pennsylvania).
Informal discussions with President Eisenhower.

Informal visit. In the U.S. March 17–April 17; visited Hawaii, San Francisco, Williamsburg and Norfolk (Virginia), Knoxville and Oak Ridge (Tennessee), Columbus (Georgia), Los Angeles, Denver and Colorado Springs (Colorado), Chicago, Springfield (Illinois), Detroit (Michigan), and New York City.
Unofficial visit. Later visited New York and Boston (Massachusetts). Left U.S. April 26; stopped in Houston (Texas) April 27–28 after visiting Canada.

State visit. Addressed U.S. Congress May 12. Afterwards visited Detroit (Michigan), Chicago, Dallas and El Paso (Texas), Los Angeles, Santa Fe (New Mexico), Omaha (Nebraska), New York City, Norfolk (Virginia), and Wilmington (Delaware). Departed U.S. May 31.
Dedicated a monument at the St. Lawrence Power Dam, Massena, New York.

Official visit at Washington and Camp David (Maryland) Afterwards visited New York City, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Des Moines and Ames (Iowa). Revisited Washington and Camp David September 25–27. Departed U.S. September 27.
Official visit. Afterwards visited New York City. Departed U.S. October 4.
Attended CENTO Ministerial Meeting.
Attended CENTO Ministerial Meeting.
State visit. Afterwards visited Chicago and New York City. After visiting Canada (October 15–18), visited Austin and the LBJ Ranch (Texas). Departed U.S. October 19.

Informal meeting with President Eisenhower. In U.S. October 11–30, led Moroccan delegation to the UN General Assembly, and visited Knoxville (Tennessee), Dallas, Phoenix (Arizona), Los Angeles, Detroit (Michigan), and Niagara Falls (New York).
State visit. In U.S. October 25–November 8. Also visited Raleigh (North Carolian), Chicago, Los Angeles, Wheeling (West Virginia), Omal (Ohio), and New York City.
